awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Optimized Extraction and Projection Optics for Ion Point Sources
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project seeks to demonstrate a technology advance in the field of imaging mass spectrometry. A successful project will enable: (1) markedly improved mass resolving power sufficient to separate key mass interferences that limit the technique, and (2) introduction of a new generation of position-sensitive ion detectors to dramatically improve data acquisition rates by 100 times and detection efficiency to 100%. These developments will create an opportunity to rethink the underlying architecture of commercial stigmatic-imaging time-of-flight mass spectrometry microscopes. With this technology, a new generation of instruments will be realized. The addressable market opportunity for these instruments is currently about $50 million per annum and is expected to grow with the new superior performance and with increasing need which grows more acute with time. Such improved instruments can beneficially impact major industries such as semiconductors ($450 billlon per year) and metals ($12 trillion per year). Improvements in the quality, quantity, and availability of atomic-scale information from imaging mass spectrometry instruments thus can have a large impact on technological progress. The advances sought in this project are the first steps toward new tools that will meet the demands of scientists and engineers for decades. 

The intellectual merit of this project is embodied in an experimental test of a new optical approach to control beam divergence from point sources of charged particles. By controlling beam divergence, ion imaging detectors can be optimally adapted to record images with superior properties. This will significantly advance fields of stigmatic-imaging mass spectrometry and ion-beam projection instrumentation. Extensive computer simulations have been conducted and used to aid design of prototype ion optics. The ability of these optics to control the ion beam divergence while projecting stigmatic ion images must be confirmed. Such ion images will be recorded over a wide range of operating conditions of the ion source and optics. A proof-of-concept experiment is proposed here to validate predictions of modeling. The quality of the projection will be assessed and compared with the simulations for validation of the models and further optimization aiming at development of a product prototype. This work will enable 1) long-sought-after imaging time-of-flight mass spectrometry measurements with large field of view and high mass resolving power for precise ion identification, and 2) implementation of a new generation of ion detectors that offer 100% detection efficiency and a hundred-fold increase in data acquisition rate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Ion beam instruments are a major tool used in characterization and synthesis of both inorganic and biological materials. In characterization experiments, the ions are typically liberated from a small point source or area and fly toward a detector. Mass spectrometry is often used to determine the identity and spatial distribution of the various ions in the emission area and thus gain valuable insight into the composition and function of materials. But imaging mass spectrometry of a diverging beam generated by point ion sources historically battles a basic dilemma. If the ions are identified by their time of flight from a pulsed source to the detector (time-of-flight mass spectrometry, TOF-MS), the mass resolving power improves with longer flight times. Hence, it is beneficial to move the detector further away from the source to achieve better mass resolution. But such arrangements can cause an increasing fraction of ions in the divergent beam to land outside the active area of the detector. This results in losses of important information. Increasing the size of detectors to catch all ions often is not practical or even feasible. On the other hand, moving the detector toward the source can fix this problem at the expense of deteriorated mass resolution due to the shorter flight time. Then information is lost too, because ions cannot be confidently identified.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project devised and conducted an experimental test of a new approach to efficiently control the beam divergence from point sources of ions. With the proposed new ion optics, the dilemma above can be overcome. Extensive computer modeling was conducted to aid the design of prototype ion optics. The optics were manufactured and tested by proof-of-concept experiments aiming to validate the modeling predictions. The results of these experiments agreed well with the modeling and demonstrated the ability of the new ion optics to efficiently control wide angular distributions of ions and deliver them to standard-sized detectors installed at optimal distances from the source. This is what is needed to improve mass resolution in commercial instruments without losses in sensitivity.

This work shows that 1) long-sought-after imaging TOF-MS measurements with simultaneous large field of view and high mass resolving power can be built and 2) a new generation of ion detectors that offer 100% detection efficiency and 100× increase of data acquisition rate can be used in commercial instruments. These gains will significantly advance fields of imaging mass spectrometry and ion beam projection instrumentation.

Broader Impacts

This Phase I project demonstrated a technological advance in the field of charged-particle optics. These developments solve outstanding technological limitations and present Steam Instruments the opportunity to rethink the underlying architecture of commercial imaging TOF-MS instruments such as those based on laser ablation. With this, Steam Instruments will develop and commercialize a new generation of such instruments with performance markedly superior to what is presently available from any other vendor. This capability will appeal to both high-end users (seeking precision and sensitivity of analyses) and high-throughput users (seeking to accomplish as many such analyses as possible in a given time).

In the world of technology, the need for spatially resolved nanometer-scale characterization of materials and devices grows more acute with time. In research and development for metallurgy, high-performance electrochemical energy storage, semiconductors, and quantum computing devices, the key to developing greater understanding and securing real progress lies with the ability to gain information about physical processes and phenomena in three dimensions and with as high lateral and depth resolution as possible. Improvements in the quality, quantity, and availability of such information from instruments like imaging mass spectrometers thus can have a large impact on technological progress. Advances in science and technology have been the foundation of societal progress for centuries. It is said that better tools beget even better tools in a virtuous circle. The twenty-first century is the age of nanometer-scale endeavor in science and technology. Hence, novel capabilities in new characterization tools have a central role to play in human progress. The advances shown in this proposal are the first steps toward new tools that will meet the demands of scientists and engineers for decades to come.
